I wanted to write this as the ongoing controversy concerning the LMH Foundation Year has left a very bitter taste in my mouth and I believe it’s important that people see this issue from another perspective. I’ll premise this by saying that the LMH FY is a complicated and unique programme in which there are few guarantees. It appears this fact has been lost in the reductive discourse posted on social media and in student publications, and it seems particularly clear that little effort has been spent contacting previous LMH FY students to gain this rather important information. Every year, LMH interviews a number of prospective students. As expected, this number is far greater than the places offered. This is similar to the standard Oxford interview process. However, where they differ is that – whilst for the standard undergraduate courses there are a guaranteed number of offers given per course per year – this guarantee does not exist for the FY. The reasons behind this are multifactorial: funding must be available, tutors must be on board with taking on FY students, appropriate students must be found, and – most importantly – the are more potential subjects that are interviewed for than there are available places. These factors change year to year. Hence, you may be the first person ever to be accepted for English; you also may be the last. Furthermore, it is possible for individuals to be interviewed for a given subject and no one subsequently receive an offer for that subject. My point here is that the way this issue has been presented is that “LMH have removed their Law Foundation Year”. There is no Law FY. There is only the FY, on which an offer for Law may or may not be given, depending on the year. Not offering this particular student does not equate to one less student being offered a place for the FY. Another, equally as worthy, student will fill that place, be it for a different subject. Another issue I take with this controversy is the manner in which it has been presented: a noble and virtuous crusade against LMH in the face of perceived anti-access actions. Let’s not forget that LMH is far and above every other college for even offering a FY in the first place and that the creation of the university-wide Astrophoria FY can be in large part be attributed to the pro-access steps taken by LMH. This situation is incredibly unfortunate and highly upsetting to the individual involved. I do not mean to minimise that by writing this post. Nonetheless, attacking and vilifying the entire institution seems excessive and the very public manner in which it has occurred seems borderline performative. It must also be considered that this individual will not have been the only person rejected from the FY, many of whom will be experiencing similar disappointment. It is unfortunate that the reasoning behind this decision was logistical as opposed to merit-based, but it certainly will not be the only decision that was made this way. The LMH FY is logistically difficult and stands loftily atop a temporary scaffold built around the undergraduate teaching system. Hopefully, the establishment of the Astrophoria FY will create more consistency. LMH will obviously be looking at this pragmatically; it is foolish to believe otherwise. Law tutors, now stretched thin, will not be able to work over their contracted hours and it is not unreasonable that they would prioritise undergraduates. It is not as simple as “finding other tutors”: LMH is the only college that offer this form of teaching and simply passing FY students off to PhD students undermines the concept that you receive an education of similar quality and rigour to undergraduates. In the aftermath of the last two years, colleges are seeing soaring costs across the board; I’m sure many of you will experience significant rent hikes next year. It is simply naïve to expect LMH to go above and beyond to facilitate a single student studying a particular course at significant extra cost when this place can be offered to a student studying a different subject. Again, this situation is desperately unfortunate for the individual it affects but it does not merit the outrage it has created.
Why is Cherwell taking LMH's side???

not at lmh but the foundation year only takes students when it deems them to be of the required standard - if there are no students that reach this standard, there will be no students for that subject that year. this student in question was not given a offer that was rescinded but was simply not given an offer at all.

I think people need to understand where the anger is coming from before jumping to conclusions that the anti-abortion stall can be platformed due to free speech. Whilst these individuals are entitled to have their own opinion on abortion and choose not to get one themselves, they are not entitled to take that choice away from women. If the basis of this society is to actively support and campaign for abortion to be banned, then why should this society be given a platform to promote rhetoric of denying women bodily autonomy. I am all for debate and encouraging discussion around polemical topics; however, I think people need to realise that OSFL aren’t seeking to encourage debate but are actively participating in misogynistic movements and campaigns which are attempting to reverse abortion laws. It’s harmful and for this to be promoted under the University’s own name is questionable, which is probably why lots of students are upset given the privilege we have to live in a country where there is a choice… TLDR: Campaign against women’s human rights and then promoting and enforcing the rhetoric on students under the guise of ‘intellectual’ debate shouldn’t be platformed in this setting.

An entirely different foundation (!), your true forebears, Magdalen Hall, was founded in the 1480s. In the 1820s Magdalen Hall revamped those destitute former Hertford College buildings and moved there cuz they needed a sweet new home. Then, in the 1870s Magdalen Hall wanted to become a College, too. Ohh shoot! Magdalen College already existed! So they needed a different name. Want to know what gives the most sus energy? Seeing 7+ posts describing how uncomfortable people feel at Teddy and responding with this weird Teddy nationalism. I've made a lot of great friends at Teddy; I've got a lot of good memories there; and sometimes it's really fun to be a student there... BUT the wider culture is so exclusionary. And it's not a hate crime to say that... In HT22 alone, there was literally a case of racist harrassment at hustings and a serious sexual assault case. The guys involved have been protected by their group of mates for a long time beforehand, when everyone knows the racist has been making racist statements since Freshers and the predator has been predatory since Freshers. This group is also a pretty dominant part of the social elements and culture of the hall. They even created weird socials like the AJCR and 'The Syndicate' - which are as embarrassingly lame as they sound, but for a lot of us, it's just an example of another thing we aren't invited to. People are legit so uncomfy with the vibe they're having to anonymously complain on Oxfess. Fun is not "just fun" at teddy. One oxfess wrote about having to eat lunch in the toilets because of how uncomfy the energy in the JCR is. What's "trendy" about that? POC feeling uncomfortable and upset with racists being socially accepted at teddy isn't "hate" and I'm not sure why it shocks people. The comment on drinking culture specifically is so relatable because the non-drinking events may be great, but it still is so alienating not drinking at teddy. This isn't on the Entz reps who are all amazing - it's about the culture created. This isn't a welfare issue. It isn't a personal attack on most students ( just to clarify for those of you who seem to lack any other identity than being a Teddy student and can't cope with any negative feeling about the place). Stop spamming Oxfess with all this defensive and dismissive teddy nationalism... If you're lucky enough to love the place, think a bit deeper about the experiences being shared here... Maybe you love the hall because you haven't experienced any form of harrassment. Maybe you're okay being friends with racists. Maybe you're just lucky enough to have missed the vibes being given out. Either way, a better response for the hall lovers in the crowd might be to start listening to the upset expressed and thinking about how to fix up.

Oxhate to priority ballots at Catz. With so many people getting access to priority for non-substantial reasons, you're creating a two tiered system which f*cks those who don't have a friend who can claim based on their disability. One class of people gets access to a first choice of the nicest accommodation, whilst the other class has to pick at scraps for sh*tty accommodation, with tiny rooms, and sometimes not even a sink.

Access to an en-suite shouldn't be reserved to the groups which can claim. It's completely unfair to create a system which rewards those who could easily cope without (you did in first year, right?), by providing such a privilege to 1+3 friends. The fact that me and my friends are completely out of the race  for nice rooms because none of us are disabled is absolutely unequitable - at least allow us to compete here please.

In cases of genuine need, I understand the essential nature of the extra facilities. The issue arises from the fact there is no longer a distinction between genuine need, and the "well I can claim, so I will, even though I don't exactly need it, and I'll pick 3 friends to come with me". I don't blame them for doing it, the system is flawed.

Priority should be for the priority holder only (or even with a +1). Allowing groups of up to 4 is taking away any fairness for everyone else. I'm certain that if you limited it to 2 people per group, you'd ensure only those who genuinely need it get it, whilst allowing for a fair competition for everyone else to secure decent rooms next year.

Complaining about the New College gradel situation hardly reeks of privilege. It’s a frustrating outcome and it’s perfectly reasonable for people to be irritated. We were told that we would be able to move into gradel at the start of term after so many people were worried about it and now look what happened. It just feels like we’re being messed around. I wouldn’t be surprised if we ended up staying in this hotel for the entire term. While college has done a good job at sorting out a back up plan, hotel rooms are not designed to be lived in for a month. Storage, laundry, socialising and so many other things are going to be severely impacted and it’s especially disheartening because it’s happening in our third year. I wonder if you’ll still feel the same way about this accommodation by the end of October…

Oxhate to the New College commemoration ball being so insanely expensive. It’s one of the most (if not the most) expensive balls I’ve seen put on. Access tickets are available for members from the lowest income households, sure, however the discount hasn’t been disclosed and even with that, the inability for their guests back home to afford the (even more expensive) tickets deter them from coming even further. And then come the insanely high costs of hiring white tie due to the “traditional” dress code. I’m sure everyone’s trying their best but surely more can be done to make it more accessible for everyone and isolating students or making their experience lesser by charging ~£250 for guest tickets as well as an extra £80 each for dining is unfair.

I had a dream last night about someone performing the song 'Old Trafford Christ Church' about financial inequalities between Oxford colleges. All I remember is that it fitted the tune of 'The Combine Harvester' and was enjoyed by the St Anne's Domestic Bursar. Since I couldn't remember the words, I asked ChatGPT to write some. Unfortunately they need a bit of work to fit the tune, but here they are:

Verse 1:
I went to Oxford for a little look-see
And found the colleges, so grand and fancy
But as I looked around, it made me feel blue
Financial inequalities, between colleges, oh what can we do?

Chorus:
Old Trafford Christ Church, a beacon for the rich
While others struggle to make ends meet, it's a glitch
The system's biased and not fair to all
Leaving some with no choice but to crawl

Verse 2:
The halls of power make the rules for the land
Leaving some behind with no chance to stand
While others go ahead and thrive
Leaving some to struggle just to survive

Chorus:
Old Trafford Christ Church, a beacon for the rich
While others struggle to make ends meet, it's a glitch
The system's biased and not fair to all
Leaving some with no choice but to crawl

Bridge:
But we won't stand still and be silenced
We'll raise our voices and be heard
For a world where financial equality reigns
And every student's chance to succeed is gained

Chorus:
Old Trafford Christ Church, no more a beacon for the rich
As fairness and equality take the pitch
The system's changed and now it's for all
Leaving no one behind to fall

Outro:
So come on, let's work together
And make this world fair and better
For the students, for the land
Equality for all, that's the plan.

There are six ways to enter and exit Christ Church Meadows after hours, which require relatively little effort:

1. Ascend and traverse along the low lying wall which is situated beside the Rose Lane gate. It’s adjoined to the small red tiled lodge.

2. The perimeter wall dividing the meadow entrance and St. Aldates can be ascended (as mention in other comments). The access point is in the direction of St. Aldates police station and is concealed by bushes.

3. To the rear of The Head of the River pub lies a footbridge, with a gateway that accesses the Christ Church Meadow Walk. Traversing to the left of the gate and vaulting the metal railings will give you access.

4. The Trill Mill Stream is an underground stream which runs between Christ Church Meadows and Castle Mill Stream. It can be kayaked or walked depending upon the time of year. A little more extreme, but it makes for a fun adventure. It can be accessed from within the garden area of the Meadow. Waders are a must!

Night Porters at the Meadow Entrance have been known to wander into the garden area after hours. So do your best to avoid this area until after 2am. Hope this helps.

re peter’s being founded on the premise of facilitating access for those of lesser means: that ship sadly sailed quite some time ago given that in the 2022 admissions cycle peters admitted *the lowest percentage of state-school educated students* out of *all* colleges :/

Peter's accommodation prices are even more despicable considering they completely go against the founding principle of our college. The purpose of St Peter's is to 'provide an oxford education to students of limited means.' That's literally why we exist. To go against that and rinse students for money is just disgraceful.

It's part of a wider trend of the terrible communication and treatment of students (undergrads only in my experience although I'm sure it's not just limited to us) by the staff of St Peter's. From the ridiculously power hungry junior Dean, to the current issues with the bar and entz stuff, there is no respect shown to the jcr from the college administration, and no attempt with any of these issues to even try and talk to students about it.

I still absolutely love our college, but very much in spite of the college administration. The JCR are amazing and our unique social life, the amazing bar and the loveliness of all undergrads to help each other still imo makes Peter's a beautiful place. But I really don't want to go back to college accommodation next year because of the honestly stupid prices, and I don't know what I'll do.

Tldr;
Oxhate to the Peter's administration and the accommodation prices.
Oxlove to the JCR and Peter's undergrads.

The problem with the campaign to no-platform Kathleen Stock is not primarily free speech. You have a right to free speech, but not a right to be invited to speak at the Union. It is a problem of bullying and respect. Prof Stock was invited because she represents one side of an active political debate in the UK, where both sides claim to be standing up for basic human rights. The Union thought a lot of members would be interesting in listening to her, whether they agree with her or not (I definitely don’t), and I expect the event (if it happens) will indeed be packed. If you don’t want to listen to Stock you don’t have to attend. You will in no way be harmed simply because she gives a talk in the same city, even if you are trans and her talk is genuinely transphobic. Trying to deprive the option from all your fellow students (including trans students) who do want to listen to her through a campaign of bullying, harassment and e.g. banning the Union from the Freshers’ Fair (something OUSU should not have the power to do for any student organisation, even a private club) is childish and deeply selfish. Try to have some basic respect for your friends and colleagues who have different views from you (including people from different backgrounds or faiths), and maybe don’t be so entitled as to assume your own position is morally perfect, or that everything that offends you personally is “hate speech”. One day you may find yourself holding the controversial opinion, or wanting to host or attend a controversial event. So be careful what you wish for.

as a queer student who really doesn't care about the union, I think trying to wrap my head around the kathleen stock situation has only made me realise quite how complicated it is. on one hand, you have media outlets talking about how freedom of speech is being infringed upon by these extreme authoritarian activists. living in such a young and progressive community honestly makes it such a shock to the system to see it painted in that light - while i think the idea of freedom of speech is something which can be considered, the way in which students are painted as naive, irrational, and stifling those who don't agree with them is always a bit disappointing really. personally, i wholeheartedly disagree with Stock's 'gender-critical' feminist views, and the fact that she literally criticised banning conversion therapy is quite frankly disgusting. But occasionally when i really try to think about it, i do almost (ALMOST) understand all those professors who signed that letter; i do see that, by definition, free speech should go for everyone. However, that doesn't mean that people with views such as Stock's deserve platforms. Letting her give a speech (from what I can gather - i have never been to a union speech and probably never will) with little/no space for criticism is not necessarily what free speech is about. I think one can argue that freedom of speech would be being stifled if she was being told by students that she could never hold a speech in the city of Oxford or talk to someone about her views on the street, but the Union is a private institution. While I completely understand that hosting a speaker does not necessarily imply endorsement of their views, hateful messages shouldn't automatically deserve a platform on the basis of free speech. I don't think 'free speech is in peril', as the Telegraph put it. if she should be free to share her views on trans people then why are students not free to disagree? I don't think protesting against hate speech is authoritarian, and I doubt the media backlash would be anywhere near the same if it were another marginalised group (while I can't speak for some, as a woman I reckon it would be different if it were an academic who was forced to resign for being deeply misogynistic). I don't think anyone thinks that there should no longer be discussions about identities, sexualities and genders, and I also don't think that the vast majority of people in discussion of this issue would agree with the endangerment of safety to anyone concerned, but the trans community deserve to have their voices heard and their rights protected. it seems to me that the crux of this whole argument is that freedom of speech goes both ways, and while she is able to discuss on her platforms her personal views, those who disagree with them are also, equally able to say that they are not interested in hearing her views, which to me seems to be what is happening. it's not as though we're not being taught in tutorials on gender that it is a complex, multifaceted issue within which there are many diverse and conflicting views both within and outside the Western world, and if somebody is interested in hearing what Stock has to say, her books are in libraries. nobody is disputing that she doesn't have a right to put her opinions out there - it just seems like students are exercising their own freedom of speech to state that they disagree with the decision of the union to platform them, especially in a context where there is little room for contention.

Regarding the recent SU-Union drama and the debates surrounding free speech associated with this on-going debacle, I think it’s important to remember that free speech does not mean speech free from response or from consequence. Just as speakers should have the right to say whatever they wish to say — as this is an essential element of enlightened democracy and a central tenet of not only academic, but also political and even social discourse — so too should the people listening to these speakers have the right to question, critique, and disagree with opinions expressed. Hence, whilst Kathleen Stock’s opinions on gender are distasteful to say the least, and even potentially harmful, surely we as a community cannot deny her right to voice these opinions? — doing so curtails dialogue and amounts to something akin to censorship, setting a dangerous precedent which potentially threatens the very basis of free discussion. If one may bar Kathleen Stock from speaking, and even seek to discourage the union from inviting controversial speakers by isolating the institution itself, what is stopping people from de-platforming speakers with less inflammatory views simply because a selection of individuals disagree with their views? That being said, Stock and the controversial speakers hosted by the union should not stand unopposed. Rather, the students of this university have a duty to challenge these speakers in order to expose the hypocrisy, or venom, of their positions. We cannot deny people the right to speak, but we can oppose the vehement rhetoric.

Here’s the actual facts about the SU and Oxford Union:

The Oxford Union is registered as a company in its own right; it is essentially a private gentleman’s ’ club / an independent business that runs events for profit. It has employees. It is subject to no oversight from the central university or the SU.

Due to this, it cannot be a student society. It is a business that runs for profit. As in, when it goes to the SU Freshers Fair they pay for a business-stand.

The SU voting to cut ties with the Union is, therefore, the same as the SU voting to no longer have anything to do with any other company - like Amazon, or Nandos. The reasoning behind the vote was not wanting to support or endorse the Union as a business.

The SU were not giving money to the Union or anything like that, they will simply no longer have official representatives of it at their events anymore.

The people who voted for this attended student council on Tuesday. It wasn’t one sole group of friends banding together to ‘take the Union down’. These meetings are open to the public and every common room has votes to allocate. Many of the regular attendees of student council have held positions within the Oxford Union; this motion still passed with a massive majority.

If you don’t like this decision and want to do something about it, you can go to the SU and get involved. This discussion was publicised in advance on the website and you can get involved by attending the next council meeting; everyone can go and every common room has votes. There has been a lot of misleading information and rumours so I am writing this to clear things up and tell you what has happened.

It's time to speak up and take action against the audacity of those who shame and silence us for criticizing the Union President. The Union is not the President's personal project to do as he pleases - it's a private members club, and we, the members, have every right to raise concerns when events like yesterday's occur.

Let's talk about the elephant in the room: the Israel Ambassador's invitation was problematic. It's not because she's Israel's ambassador, but because of who she is and what she stands for. Tzipi Hotovely is an ultra right wing politician who has described herself as "a religious right winger" and rejects the very existence of the Palestinian people. She supports the annexation of the entire West Bank and Gaza, and has an appalling record of racist and inflammatory behaviour.

Hundreds of British Jews signed a petition against her nomination as ambassador and there was a big protest the last time she was here. Yet our Union President saw fit to invite her again, just a few months after her last visit. She was not here for a dialogue, but to propagate her racist agenda. The last time she was here she received a red-carpet welcome with cherry-picked questions from the President. See the interview here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d1zSHoXEFmw . And this time it was a panel discussion but where were the Palestinians in all of this? Why wasn't there any representation from the people most affected by her policies? If the President wanted a dialogue here, why were the Palestinians not represented?

To make matters worse, her security team manhandled and profiled students for "security reasons". Is this what we want our Union to be - a security state that discriminates against its own members? And why were there different standards - members with Palestinian stickers or symbols were not allowed in? Moreover, it is not the first time Union had high-profile speakers with security issues, but never had the members faced profiling or discrimination.

It's time for us to hold our Union President accountable and demand better. We cannot stay silent in the face of injustice and bigotry. Our Union is supposed to be a space for open dialogue and debate, not a platform for hate speech and discrimination. Let's stand together and make our voices heard - we deserve better than this. Sign the No Confidence Motion!

regarding the Union drama: outside of the controversy about the guest, there is a very pressing concern about members’ privacy and security. It’s one thing for security to be intimidating, it’s another thing for state security to be photographing and recording pro-Palestinian members attending the talk. Given the delicate nature of the Palestinian occupation, it’s very dangerous to have state security recording individuals, esp those who are Palestinian, and could have very real consequences. The fact the Union did not consider the privacy and safety of their members, nor acknowledge post hoc what had happened nor make a statement saying they will do better is very concerning. There were members wearing a hijab or a keffiyeh who got to the door of the Union chamber last trinity, realised the state security were recording them and felt their safety would be threatened if they were to stay. No member should be made to feel this way, nor should the union have allowed it, especially as the members had not done anything to warrant being regarded as a threat that needed to be recorded or photographed.
Absolutely baffling how the Union President can be involved in a scandal every term, regardless of who is in the seat. Really have to wonder what this says about the Union as a whole.

Instead of agitation to limit speech at union, how about agitate to include more pro-Palestine speakers? Also, I think the no-confidence vote is kinda shit considering it's based on rather subjective (biased) descriptions that are widely prone to bias on a topic in which all parties feel strong passion for. Surely it's fair to feel passion for what's happening over there, but to say protesters were completely peaceful would also be an overstatement.

The problem is not with the Israeli ambassador coming to speak at the Union. The problem is that the last time she came, her security were intimidating, didn’t let the Palestinian flag go in and the discussion itself allowed very minimal questioning of her (frankly, abhorrent) views. On top of this, there was only 48 hours notice before her arrival. None of this the union apologised for or even tried to fix the second time around. Don’t go on about free speech if it’s one rule for them and one rule for the rest. Do better.

RE: The people claiming "free speech and debate" regarding anti-LGBT Union speakers, I'd like to ask: What is there, exactly, to debate about LGBT rights in that context? Those arguing from a religious perspective are motivated by dogma that cannot be reasoned against. This is how you look: Gay person: I would like to exist please. The right to be myself without facing discrimination would be nice also. Guest speaker: Your existence is a mistake and an affront to my religion. I disagree with you being the person that you are. This is why people are upset, because the topic of 'debate' is so often basically whether they should receive equal rights and civil liberties to anybody else. Some people love to claim they're "just concerned", like in the case of trans healthcare, but when you strip it back, usually this is a presentable way of saying these people make you uncomfortable by existing (which has no value in an argument, least of all silly little debates like the Union ones, where emotion is meant to be put aside because we're all so smart and logical).

Gut instinct says that the reason why people are upset over controversial speakers being invited to the Union is that being invited is prestigious in itself. Oxford Union is a prestigious institution and to get an invitation to speak is an opportunity and in a sense a reward. Although inviting such people to speak allows us to speak against them and make our counterarguments known, inviting a person who holds unacceptable views rather than someone who can enrich us with positive ideas seems strange. Ultimately when an arrogant, self-important person is invited to speak, applauded on entrance, made to sit at the front, given a microphone, and given the opportunity to present in such a grandiose building, how could they not see their presence and therefore ideas, as anything other than endorsed by the Union.
Why can't the Union get more pop culture speakers a la the Cambridge Union this term - they have WillNE, Daniel Levy and Rylan while we're stuck with random politicians no one cares about.

#oxfess19838 The motion itself is about same-sex marriage in the church which as a Queer person who was brought up Christian is something I definetely see the merits of debating. I wanna see what leading clergy who are well versed on the topic have to say for both sides. The Union hosting a motion which is actively been debated in the Church of England and other Christian denominations across the world is merely an acknowledgement that these debates are happening, if you'd rather silence the conversation and pretend like everyone is on board with LGBTQ+ rights you are delusional. For example only 55% of Anglicans believe same sex marriage is 'right', far from a consensus. Talking about LGBTQ+ rights, and debating the issues that are currently been discussed within and outside the community is important especially in an educational context such as in a debating society at University. I wanna be able to articulate the best possible arguments for religious same-sex marriages that I can, and seeing a debate on the issue is one of the best ways to get a grip on the topic and empower me to find the right words to speak up.

I’m all for bashing the Union but this term’s had too many oxfess’ targeting the audacity of having a large event be non-alcoholic and it’s a seriously concerning attitude. Let them decide the price they’ll set according to their demographic and their price sensitivity-if you don’t want to pay for the experience, don’t?? The idea of a “non drinking ball” shouldn’t trigger people nearly as much as it seems to-as a previous oxfess has mentioned, loads of people choose not to drink for all kinds of reasons (religion only being one-constantly screaming Puritanism is a disservice not just to everyone not drinking due to health, financial or other reasons but also to those who’s relationship with their faith informs this decision, which isn’t something that should be disrespected for no apparent reason??). I don’t think that when we look back on our fondest moments here we’re all able to recall exclusively the nights we spent absolutely pissed. It’s a cool and accessible thing to have some diversity in events across the city, and my props to committees trying that- my support doesn’t necessarily extend to any of the institutions they represent but I love them for trying something here. Hope to see one succeed at some point.

There really is nothing quite as triggering as the male Oxford student. Clad in brown, zipped-up wax jacket, red chinos and Apple airpods, he grips the straps of his leather messenger bag as he makes his way to Quod to meet an out-of-college friend for coffee. It’s early - a 8:30am meet to be precise - but he’s been up since 7am to draft hack messages and practice his oratory skills (something he’s done ever since A-levels - which he didn't do too amazingly in but mummy pulled some strings). After coffee, he’ll head to the Union member's bar, thinking about the sheer SCANDAL of state school overrepresentation in PPE (despite his cohort being literally 40% privately educated). Then, after a few hours of networking, he’ll have 1 drink at Cafe Nero with his fellow PPE chums, before heading to Varsity to make the most of his university experience by buying 1 shot of tequila and immediately volunteering to take the drunk girl (who insists she’s fine - but our subject insists otherwise) home at 1am. Still completely sober, he’ll slip into bed smug with the knowledge that, while everyone else is rotting the next morning, he’ll be up bright and early to do it all again.

I think it's interesting when you hear people ask how can you change the union so it's less 'uniony' because the real answer is you can't?

There's two reasons for that: 
1. social fabric and nepotism of public school boys (obviously not saying that's the whole union but it's a large part) 
2. the constitution and structure itself.

On the social fabric, no matter how much they say they're interested in increasing diversity and access, they quite clearly aren't. The drama this week reveals that. They cry because he didn't attend an access meeting, but ruin an entire access visit in the process. Access is a means to an end for them.

On the structure itself, just read the Cherwell article. It's a breeding ground for Westminster, arbitrary roles and rules to make them feel like they're important like my brothers in Christ you are in a university club not the NATO. Yes you're handling a budget, but 'authoritarianism'. Grow up.

And for those looking for an alternative group, ultimately any group structured in that way will wind up working in the same way. Our only option would be for the other groups in Oxford primarily centred on either a political or marginalised groups (Femsoc, LGBTQ+ soc, ACS, 93%, OULC, OUCA, even the Lib Dems if we must, etc.) to join forces. Otherwise those minority viewpoints will slowly be forced out by zealous and loud people in any larger group, as it is in the union. That will probably never happen because there isn't the central admin or money that the union has, but it's a nice vision to see something that resembles an actual 'union' of people.

PSA for anyone wanting to get involved with the Oxford drama scene; forget OUDS and just join the Union. Genuinely shocked by how much poor conduct there is and how many scandals are arising. The steep bureaucracy, lack of integrity, concerning power dynamics and general lack of respect that is often displayed is disgraceful. How on earth any future committees will be able to enact positive change, I do not know (although I really hope people will try, and eventually succeed). The lack of accountability and transparency is just so disappointing. The whole management hierarchy and structure of the system is really hindering respectful, transparent discussions and I genuinely hope that something is done to reform things to try and enable people to do their jobs, benefit from being involved and improve members' experiences, rather than having to waste so much time and effort on things that lead to no results, constant hostility and must be emotionally draining. Good luck

If... (just hear me out) IF we all just... stopped caring about the Union, it would go away, right? I know people pretend not to care but then they pore over the drama or complain about it's cliques/elitism/[insert negative trait]; that's not not caring, that's not liking but you still care. It just seems like the whole university goes through waves of periodically ironically engaging in the Union's bullshit, then forgetting it's ironic and just engaging, then back to purported irony. If we all actually just stopped, it wouldn't have enough interest to sustain itself. Sure, the die-hards would keep at it for a while but they'd have to give up eventually, because the incentives (based on connections/power/pretending not to be a lizard in a human suit by hiding in a crowded chamber) would diminish with the number of participants. It's a bit like Instagram, if we all agreed it was valueless, it would lose it's power over us. Can we try? Apart from anything else, just imagine how satisfying it would be to see all the sad, deflated hacks who put all their time into it and then realise they're actually just a bunch of overgrown teenagers playing parliament, unsure if they actually have any friends (lizard people don't count). If things got really good, they would have to start selling the land or something to remain solvent: imagine! I'm finishing this year and my intention is to rid my Facebook friends list of Unionites about as thoroughly as a dictator purges intellectuals and artists from a failed state; if anyone wants to get me a graduation gift, just deliberately avoid anything to do with the Union, pretend it doesn't exist. If nothing else, it would be so funny to watch them crumble.

I have seen quite a few posts related to buying tickets to upcoming Union Ball and many other big events.

I honestly am not against the events themselves, but it's hard to feel like it's worth going to when the people organising and the society/organisation they represent haven't had the best history (especially looking at you, Oxford Union). It feels like if I'd attend these balls I'm indirectly supporting societies which weren't able to deal with issues such as harassment, sexual assault and discrimination in the correct way.

If you see someone against participating at these events, remember this aspect too. I'm not a person of strong principles, but at the same time, it's hard not to be disgusted by the repeated inability to deal with these situations. Yes, there will always be failures in dealing with such issues (we are not anywhere near perfect; even the university is not doing great in that regard, that shows it has its own problems), but having a problem like this almost every single term is a sign of something being wrong with the culture and enviroment of that society.

Take care everyone, and I don't condemn anyone who is attending or wishes to, but keep this in mind.

The company that owns the Plush brand signed a lease from the Oxford Union to take over the current location in 2019. Prior to that, the student nightclub there had been known as the Purple Turtle (or ‘PT’) for 20 years. It had its own atmosphere that matched the underground dinge of the building, while the central location, roomy smoking area, etc were part of the draw for people. It was very popular among students and while some things have changed since the club became Plush (eg rock or faux-alt nights = no longer so much), many other things about it haven’t.

John’s ball was a pretty great night and clearly committee put a lot of work into it. Drinks never ran out, Oxford bands & dancers were great as usual, trippy light displays, silent disco til 6am, Mura Masa didn’t play his own songs but the mix was good. Main issue was the queuing. Oh my god the food queues. Waiting an hour for a tiny portion was enough for people to decide to go hungry for the rest of the night. (Same for the swings, the shisha bar before everyone just sat wherever, and some of the bars). Security-wise, it’s so funny that the Oxfess about organisers spreading fake info about security (like the sniffer dogs) to scare people breaking in was true. Checking wristbands between quads was both annoying and didn’t work. Also security talking about tackling people… not on. The layout was weird because in theory you couldn’t do a loop of the college because Tommy White Quad was closed but porta-potties weren’t really signposted so people broke into Tommy White and used that for toilets. Also the fact that for part of the night, two men weren’t allowed on the swings until they proved they were gay… None of that really ruined the night though.
Oxlove to the guy who snuck into John's ball by hiding in a musical instrument cupboard for hours and was super stressed about leaving the pink colour quad - hope you made it through!

I managed to sneak into both John’s and then Magdalen last night (security was surprisingly lax as the night wore on). Whilst both were good fun, I can genuinely say Magdalen was the most brilliant event I’ve been to in my time at Oxford, with the best value for money of any ball in history. The fireworks were good but fuck me, the Hunna… For all the pre-ball dismay at a relatively unknown headliner, they were absolutely incredible - the last truly great rock band imo.

I have never even stepped foot into Balliol, and know nothing whatsoever about their ball. However, I feel obliged to have an opinion on all the current Oxfess drama, so I would like to state that there has never been a single worse event put on by a more grotesque group of people than the Balliol ball. I spent my last £170 to attend, and with no money left for food, with the ball not providing any, am currently starving. I have also been diagnosed with severe PTSD stemming from the sheer horror of the entire event

I’m convinced that everyone who thought the balliol ball was worth the £170 it cost does not think £170 is a considerable sum of money. I don’t know why it needed to be a commemoration ball and also have the price of a commemoration ball rather than just a normal ball, which is what it felt like. I feel very ripped off. Im sure the committee did a great job with what they had but I think people are justified in being upset over shilling out that much money for a very average oxford ball.

Baliol Ball was an absolute ordeal. For the ticket price, I expected a large screen displaying a finely curated selection of Subway Surfers gameplay and South Park clips and yet no such provision was made. How on earth was I supposed to "enjoy" an event deficient in such basic necessities?

I’ve never written an Oxfess in my life but couldn’t stand by and watch the Balliol committee get a bad rep for that ball. I’ve been to 5 in my time here and it was easily the best I’ve been to. I do not understand who these people are and whether they actually came to the ball.

Oxlove to the Balliol Ball Committee members for organizing an amazing ball, and for being so kind and collected despite the abuse they suffered throughout the night. I was let back in by a committee member who was still shaking from people screaming at her. It's important to remember that these committee members volunteer their free time and dedicate hundreds of hours to ensure that everyone has a great time. It's saddening to see that some people (who probably never organized anything like it) resort to negative comments on Oxfess without truly appreciating the hard work and dedication that goes into organizing such events.

I knew a couple of people on the balliol ball committee and tbh I’m not surprised it was disappointing. I get that the backlash is not nice and some people on committee clearly worked very hard but having been there on the night the whole thing was disorganised, under-resourced and just a bit bland. For months said committee members have been talking about how they were only on committee so they would get free tickets and boasted that they never went to committee meetings. When a first yeargot too drunk on the night and her friends asked one of them where the first aid was they replied something along the lines of ‘F*** knows, the ball’s started, I’m only here to have a good time’. And, despite the email sent to oxfess admins, the allegation of committee hoarding Prosecco is TRUE - there was literally an instagram story in the morning of two of them walking along holywell street drinking it from the bottle in tuxedos. All in all - we want our money back!!!

Lots of talk recently about University Challenge and supposed the Oxbridge college bias. The reality is, is that the UK student quiz championships are dominated by Oxbridge when we submit a uni wide team. Our *B* team is arguably the fourth best team in the history of UK student quizzing, behind our A team, C*mbridge and Balliol (when we submitted colleges). Without wanting to brag, the college entrances for Uni challenge massively disadvantages us. We are simply better at quizzing than everyone else and would win every year if we submitted a single team, so I’d be seriously careful what you wish for.

The people talking about "jaundice at Baliol" on here really need to watch their tongues. It's inaccurate, fearmongering, and frankly if people are actually developing jaundice, posting about it as if it's just a piece of scandalous gossip is disrespectful to the people who have contracted something which could potentially be serious.

First of all, stop talking as if jaundice is contagious in the way that the common cold is. The only way people can "spread" jaundice is through hepatitis, which in turn is spread through blood or bodily fluids i.e. most likely sex. Hepatitis can lead to liver cancer or liver failure in some cases. If there is genuinely jaundice (i.e. hepatitis) going around, the most sensible thing to do is to get tested and maybe take a step back from having sex with people who you don't know too well and may potentially be carrying.

Tldr jaundice at Baliol isn't "spreading" in the way covid does, it spreads through sex and can be serious, if you're worried then get tested.

Around 22:20 on the 9th of August, I was walking through Jowett Walk to get back to my college accommodation, and saw a middle-aged man lingering suspiciously by Balliol student residence, looking up at something. When I walked by him, I looked up at the exact same spot. I had a view of a girl in a short skirt standing at the top of the staircase, which can be seen from outside from the bottom. I returned to the same spot 10 minutes later to double check, and the man was still in the same spot looking up at the same skirt. I called up the porter at Balliol immediately but was told to call a different location instead since it is out of their proximity. I'm not sure why the burden has to be on me if I was simply reporting what I saw for the sake of the safety of the students they should be protecting 🤷 Girls, please be alert when using those stairs.

Brasenose is considered one of the top-tier colleges in Oxford due to its strong academic reputation, excellent tutorial system, and vibrant community. It boasts a rich history and offers a wide range of subjects, making it an ideal choice for students looking for a well-rounded education.
Oxwhy do brasenose have a patch of grass called the deer park when they have no deer 🦌.

Dear Oxford,

I've got some groundbreaking news that's sure to leave you starstruck - Brasenose is staging a coup, and I don't mean a few renegade students setting up a rogue tuck shop in the JCR. Nope, we're talking a full-blown, high stakes, no-holds-barred takeover of the University.

The master plan? Every college to be renamed in honour of Brasenose. Picture it: Brasenose East (formerly Christ Church), Brasenose West (formerly Magdalen), and my personal favourite, Brasenose-in-the-Vale (formerly, you guessed it, Somerville). There's already a campaign for the Rad Cam to be christened the "Rad Brasenose."

And don't get me started on the dress code. "Subfusc? More like sub-fail," the new regime says. From now on, it's Brasenose-themed onesies for all examinations. Tripos in a unicorn onesie? Don't mind if I do.

Rumour has it, they're even replacing Latin grace in hall with a recitation of the lyrics to "Sweet Caroline," because, you know, 'B-N-C'. It's all in the name of tradition, they insist.

But fear not, dear Oxford, for there is a way out of this impending chaos. If we can beat them at the annual tortoise race, the takeover gets called off. So, if you have a speedster tortoise hidden away somewhere, now would be a good time to bring it forth.

I, being the most brilliant physicist that has ever graced the halls of Brasenose College, Oxford, must confess my most peculiar crime. I must confess, my dear friends, that I have committed the crime of stealing the Dean's toupee.

Now, I know what you may be thinking. "How could a genius such as yourself stoop so low as to steal a toupee?" But I must tell you, dear friends, that I was inebriated beyond belief. I had just finished a night of heavy drinking with my fellow physics enthusiasts, and I stumbled upon the Dean's office. There it was, sitting on top of his bookshelf, glimmering in the moonlight.

And so, I took it. I don't quite remember why, but I took it. I must have thought it was a necessary experiment in the field of physics, or maybe I was just trying to prove my superior intellect.

But let me tell you, my dear friends, it was not worth it. The next morning, I woke up to find the toupee sitting on my pillow, and five emails demanding an explanation.

So, here I stand, confessing to my crime. I can only hope that the Dean will show mercy and not expel me from the prestigious institution that is Brasenose.

In conclusion, I urge all of you to not follow in my footsteps. The toupee stealing business is not worth it, trust me.

Yours,
The Toupee Bandit

@BNC, what is going on over there in the admissions department?! It's crazy: in 2009, you suddenly jumped from c. #10 to #2 in no. of applications, maintaining that until hitting #1 in 2013. @W pushed you back to #2 in 2019, and for the 2020 cycle you're in 5th, but that's a messed up year overall because all offers were honoured. Dear #oxfess24948,

On the matter of pigs and piggish behaviour in CCC, I fear you may be right. Today, at some early sunlit hour, I reached CCC just a bit before the scouts. Straight away, in the Front Quad, after I scraped some Corpus Day debris off my shoe, I found a trough of evidence for your claim: a sloppy bowl of unfinished porridge oats, set upon a plant pot (indeed, set to the height of a pig). In fact, the meal is still there over an hour later, which I note only as proof that no one came back to finish their slop.

Now, we all know that sloppy quad porridge alone cannot make a sty of a whole college, even a college that dedicated its name to someone who was literally born in a barn. I duly chalked it off as “strike one” for the day, but piggy little hoofs were now firmly in my mind.

So, I took my unbothered facade to the Corpus Christi Toilet, and lo—in this second bowl I found: a big, filthy, unflushed shit. Recoiling, I stepped back from the pungent, wretched fog they left behind, only for my foot to land with cushioned horror upon a pile of used paper towels that tickled their way inside my trouser leg like a drove of truffle-hunting snouts, grunting and snortling at my exposed calf. They say pigs will eat anything. I screamed.

Still, I resolved to clear away this Corpus Oinker’s mess before the scouts arrived. Soon enough, no plausible excuses remained for this apparent act of piggery. Most importantly, lest I forget, and I regret to add: the flush worked fine. I know this because I flushed it. Nor did the vile loaf then struggle to clog itself for the joy of stealing one more breath of our surface air. Rather, it flushed with grace, just as you or I might slip down a five-star ride at Alton Towers.

But they didn’t even try to flush. I'm sure of it. Flushing never trotted through their porcine mind. Did they even wipe? The scarcity of paper in the bowl should give us pause. But we can be sure of this much—their lifestyle of filth must stop. I do not know your name, villain, but I know your soul: you are a beast of a Corpuscle. Worse, I fear you are not alone.

(TL;DR @ CCC babes - tidy up, wipe your bum, flush the loo.)

Dear "Simpkin" (Hertford cat), 

I beg of you, please, please stop coming into the Exeter lib. Settle your feud with Walter elsewhere. 

We know the lib is warm and quiet and we acknowledge there's that huge box of kibble by the automatic door... it must be hard to resist, Simpkin. But if you keep coming in here, stinking out the place with your grimy fur, goading Walter into a hissing fight, biting people (!!), we will have to take more severe measures to keep you out, Simpkin.

Next time, it won't just be a chair you're sleeping on being carried sanctimoniously down the stairs and out the door by a DPhil student shouting 'shoo shoo, you little bastard'... Oh no, Simpkin. Truly Simpkin, and I mean this from the bottom of my heart, Piss off. 

Yours sincerely,

Hertford making their Diwali celebration a BME only formal is ridiculous and honestly really upsetting for those of us who now don't get to celebrate our own religion's festival because of what we look like.  As a white adoptee into an Indian family, I am now Hindu myself and I honestly was really looking forward to celebrating Diwali with my college friends this year, but guess we're just not welcome at the religious festival we were raised with.  Even though BME people who don't even celebrate the festival are allowed to go to the celebration, white Hindus are not welcome and that just seems so unfair to me. I get so few opportunities to celebrate the culture and faith I was raised in and was hoping this might be a good opportunity, but no. Adoptees literally get the worst of both worlds - we don't know the culture we were born in, and we're rejected from the culture we were raised in.

OxL to the sad individual that made the post on Hertford’s history

History lesson for you lot. Listen Up. Stop claiming that you are founded in the 1280s. You were founded a good 200 years later, in the 1490s! Hart Hall was founded in the 1280s, became Hertford College in 1740 but was DISSOLVED in 1816. No money, no leadership. Gone. Forever. An entirely different foundation (!), your true forebears, Magdalen Hall, was founded in the 1480s. In the 1820s Magdalen Hall revamped those destitute former Hertford College buildings and moved there cuz they needed a sweet new home. Then, in the 1870s Magdalen Hall wanted to become a College, too. Ohh shoot! Magdalen College already existed! So they needed a different name. And they chose to name it Hertford College just cuz half a century ago a flimsy College with that name existed around there. This means the present day Hertford College has nothing to do with Hart Hall founded in the 1280s and has everything to do with Magdalen Hall founded in the 1490s.

A REVIEW OF JESUS COLLEGE TOILETS

Habakkuk Room 5/5: 

This toilet is the peak of comfort and privacy, in many ways it's a dream come true. It's almost always free and always clean. Although there are two minor downsides. It's a bit warm in the latter half of Trinity, though not too bad. Also if you don't know what time to use it, you can get locked in the building, in which case you'll face the embarrassment of the porter coming to save you. Have your phone with you if you don't wanna be banging on the glass door for someone to save you.

Cheng Hub 4.5/5:

Less private than the Habakkuk Room as the Hub gets quite busy sometimes and the toilets get frequently used, but it's also a little cleaner than Habakkuk. The biggest downside is that it's hard to get WiFi.

Cheng Cafe 4/5

Possibly the third least private, as it's a single toilet surrounded by the cafe itself, and you can hear everyone. This is a major downside, but otherwise the toilet is like the Hub one with WiFi.

MCR 3.5/5

I don't use this that often, but as the MCR is usually dead, it's generally private. Although it's still a bit bad looking and uncomfortable.

Staircase V 3/5

Same as MCR, except less clean, and feels more out in the open because it's in the First Quad.

JCR: 2.5/5

The second least private as the JCR is relatively active, always smells bad, and always feels dirty. Also the motion sensor can't be triggered from inside the cubicle, so if it's the evening prepare for total darkness after a few minutes.

Bar 2/5

Although I'm sure this toilet is sometimes private and clean, it never is when the bar is active, which is when you'd wanna use it anyway. So when you do go here it'll be incredibly busy. Go to Cheng Hub instead.

Library 0.5/5

What is this? Why does this toilet exist? The sink is so small and the pressure is so high I can't even wash my hands here. Not private, not clean, and the size of a locker room. Also surprisingly frequently used, and some people are incapable of locking the door. I want to forget this toilet exists.

Why is Keble Café and Pizza Bar closed on Saturdays? When I was a student there, these were open 7 days a week during full term. The café (which was in the Douglas Price Room back then) was always popular with people who could do work there while having something to eat or drink from the café. The pizza bar (also known as the Red Brick Oven) was popular in the evening, including on Saturdays when people would often use the bar and have a pizza. It was still open on Saturdays in early 2020 as I remember visiting Oxford on a Saturday in late February 2020 and having a pizza there; there were a number of others also having pizza. However, when I was in Oxford on a Saturday this February, I popped in to Keble only to find that the café and pizza bar are closed on Saturdays. Why was this decision taken, depriving Keble students of somewhere to get food while they work during the day and of somewhere to meet up and have pizza in the evening?

Bitch please. Too many Mansfield students are a bunch of privileged “state schooled” students from (upper) middle class backgrounds pretending to be disadvantaged. If the average house price in your area is £600,000, I hate to break it to you, but you’re not on the same level as Joe Bloggs from a Tower Hamlets council estate who grew up living hand to mouth on benefits.

Here’s are some absolute rockers that I’ve heard in my time at this college:

“Kids in Africa are eating better than this hall food”

My case in point😍

Also, in response to the comment about students at Mansfield not getting in at other colleges, please stop. Your just giving these elitist pricks more reason to challenge or existence and say we don’t belong here.

I’m a state school student at Mansfield, and I would completely agree with this if it wasn’t for the important caveat of the work that Mansfield does in genuinely contextualising admissions. After speaking to my tutors in college about it and hearing their stories from other colleges, it really is night and day when comparing how Mansfield admissions tutors approach a state school application vs a private school application. The scoring takes into account seriously (as opposed to in a tokenistic fashion) the tangible disadvantages of applying from a poor state school, of disabilities, of lack of access to interview or admissions test practice. I completely agree with you that in the money sense, Mansfield is an abysmal choice for students from low-income households, when compared to the financial support on offer at a place like ChCh. However, disappointingly, Mansfield is one of the few colleges putting in the hard work into making the admissions stage fairer. It’s not right, but the truth is, many of us know that we would not have got in elsewhere, not because of our lack of ability, but because of tutors at other colleges refusing to take privilege into account, or refusing to take it into account enough. While the points you make are reasonable and important, I don’t think I’d, in good faith, be able to recommend a state school applicant, especially a low income applicant, to apply anywhere else apart from Mansfield for these reasons. As soon as other colleges up their game in the admissions area though, then yeah fair enough, I think other, richer colleges become a far better shout for low income applicants

It is extremely annoying being basically tricked into applying to Mansfield as a person from the lower class, by state school statistics, only to find out they don't have the money to make sure you don't starve.

if you’re offended by the merton gowns thing that shows a lot more about you than it does about the people asking for changes to be made. it’s really not about the gowns, it’s about the inherent classicism and elitism and the sense of hierarchy and imposter syndrome that the college, tutors, students etc keep on feeding. it’s about making college a safe and comfortable place so that no one has to feel left out or constantly reminded of their academic result, it’s about no one having to miss out on college events because they don’t want to be made to feel like shit. we all know it’s just a piece of fabric mate and don’t worry no one’s taking your gown from you. everyone will still know you’re a scholar, just like they’ll know that you also lack a basic level of empathy and value upholding old traditions over college events being inclusive and an enjoyable experience for everyone.

Why is everyone so pressed about the gowns becoming optional for formals at merton? No one is trying to take away your gowns, I still plan on wearing my commoners one bc I like the tradition but some people may not feel comfortable showing what grade they got in prelims so visually - you don't know the circumstances behind someone's prelims grade. Also the whole idea that I don't like x so no one can have x (or vice versa) is problematic at the best of times and that seems to be the only argument I've seen so far as to why gowns should be mandatory. Keep wearing your gowns if you want to, I personally love seeing them being worn, but let others make the choice on whether they wear theirs or not, have some empathy

The wall dividing Merton Street and Deadman’s Walk can be scaled. Providing you land yourself in Merton’s Fellows’ Garden, you can access Merton Street. Move across the garden to the Northern Perimeter wall. From here you can either get onto Merton street by going to the East or West corner of the Garden. The East corner has climbing spikes which make for excellent hand holds for dropping into the street below. A little more caution is advised here.

My dear soldiers of St Hugh's, As your fearless leader and esteemed Admiral Flapjack, I must address you on the state of our ongoing battle with our bitter rivals at St Anne's. I am pleased to report that our recent theft of the beaver has thrown them into a frenzy, and they are surely scrambling to come up with a response. However, we cannot rest on our laurels. We have heard rumors that St Anne's are planning to steal my beloved brother, Professor Biscuit, and myself. As an admiral, I have faced many foes on the high seas, but none quite as ridiculous as this. I will not stand for this affront to our honor and dignity as cats and members of the St Hugh's community. We cats are not pawns to be used in their silly little game. I must address the issue of the beaver. Yes, we may have taken it from St Anne's, but let's face it, they were asking for it. That beaver was clearly in need of a new home, and we simply provided it with one. It's not our fault that St Anne's is so attached to their beaver, but they should have known better than to leave it unguarded. So, my fellow felines, let us not forget why we are fighting. We are fighting for our pride, our honor, and our right to sleep for 18 hours a day without disturbance. We will not let St Anne's take what is rightfully ours, and we will not back down from this war. Let us show them that we will not be cowered by their silly pranks and attempts at stealing our most prized possessions. We will rise victorious from this feud.

Oxlove to the Anne’s Pres VP and Entz (and the other freshers’ week helpers!) You guys clearly put a lot of effort in and were lovely people to all of us. Despite the night tours, games nights, family dinners, picnic, movie nights, various drop ins and people always being around in the JCR there’ll always be a few people who won’t like what you do/put on for us. It’s not your fault they want you to make their friends for them. Can’t please everyone.

Hey OP, I’m an irrelevant 4th year at Anne’s who doesn’t drink and also had a boring freshers’ week in which I didn’t go clubbing (I also didn’t go to most of the non-alcoholic events they did put on for us because I was too shy lol).

Obviously it’s not great that there apparently weren’t any events catered to non-drinkers, but in case you were worried about not having made friends in freshers’ week, I wanted to reassure you that you still have so much time to make friends - whether inside Anne’s or outside, with people that went clubbing in freshers’ week or not. Personally I also felt for most of Michaelmas term like I’d missed out on the chance to make close friends during all the freshers’ week clubbing, but in hindsight there really wasn’t anything to worry about - I got closer to existing friends and made new friends throughout Hilary term, 2nd year, 3rd year, and beyond. You could even find friends that you eventually feel comfortable going sober clubbing with, like I did!

I’ve probably been projecting my fresher experiences onto a random Oxfess, but hopefully this can help anyone who’s reading this and also feeling FOMO. Having an underwhelming freshers’ week doesn’t mean anything in the grand scheme of things, I promise :)

People complaining about the Jesus Somerville ball - get a GRIP it was one night and not everyone was going to be pleased. It was clear that the people who organised this ball put a lot into this and spent months preparing. It’s so easy for people to scrutinise when they’re not part of the process (I’m also just an attendee not involved in the any part of the organisation so this is unbiased). This breeding of self-entitled mentality is exactly the problem in this place. Claim your rights about every single scrap of what’s important to you that you forget the bigger picture. Most people that love to complain here likely have had it their way their entire life.

it was nice of the Somerville-Jesus ball committee to organise a prayer room and facilities for Muslims students, but it was a bit late in the day, considering none of us Muslim students bought tickets because there were no provisions when tickets were released. Seemed a bit performative and I’m going to be honest, I’m kind of sick of being an afterthought
To the guy with his girlfriend outside Somerville who gave me his wristband to the SJ ball - I owe you infinitely. (Made it in)

So I'm neither interested in attending or avoiding the SJ Ball, but as it stands, as a Somerville student, I have three choices:

1) Attend a ball I'm not interested in, and spend £100 odd pounds for the privilege.
2) Find alternative lodgings or get a train ticket home.
3) Stay in my room, in which case I'll be unable to enter or leave my accommodation building from 5pm to 2am.

Sure, that I can't stay at the ball is in my license agreement, but the organizers have allowed me and others not attending to stay on the condition of (3). But is it really that difficult to let me in/out without assuming I'm gonna sneak into the ball - surely just cone off the area as I live right next to the back gate of the college anyway?

Either way, what is this license agreement, which says that college can kick me out for a night some weeks before my exams so that they can all have a booze up? Imposter syndrome much!

I fucking hate Somerville as a college. My experience has been awful. It is the people who have absolutely ruined my experience. The cliques are unbearable, especially those that perpetuate the stereotype of the public school Londoners who know the same people and ask you what school you went to. The "House" is emblematic of the overwhelming privilege and callousness that characterises Somerville as a college. Whether it's ordering Ubereats coco-pops or being unbearably cruel to a girl with mh issues, there is a clear disconnect from the real world. I am surrounded by people with overwhelming privilege and conceit who have had their hands held through the system and will continue to prosper off the backs of others. I swear to God, if I have to talk to ONE more person about rugby or rowing, I will go mad. Fuck the elitist environment, fuck the fake state school friendly image, fuck Somerville.

Oxhate to OUCA, for so, so many reasons.

For the fact they found it appropriate to advertise to students - all students, regardless of class -  during the cost of living crisis, just to remind people that when their families and friends are without food, heating and lights this winter, there are a group of students celebrating.

For the fact they crewdated with the Irish Soc, seemingly oblivious to the blatant disrespect this caused.

For the fact that they always instinctively defend themselves, instead of having an empathetically-worded discussion, even when it's apparent that another party has a point. Ignoring or deflecting the fact that you are okay with 12,000 deaths this winter during the cost of living crisis caused by Truss' government just shows you are unwilling to accept that your party is not always perfect, and presents you not only as malicious but also dense.

Oxhate to the completely inconsiderate article they posted about abortion rights - the date that this was posted being so close to the overturning of Roe v Wade was completely inappropriate, and incited fear in many vulnerable women. If threatening women's feelings of comfort and safety is appropriate to you, you are a misogynist, regardless of your gender.

And finally, Oxhate to the defensive comments that I know will appear on this post. I understand the argument of 'it is natural to defend yourself from criticism' but such discussion should be considerate and appropriate, not dismissive or aggressive.

Shout out to the GTC ball, hands down the best one I’ve been to at Ox 🚀 It had everything. Huge variety of interesting food and drinks (the alcoholic milkshakes, greenbox, white rabbit pizza to name a few), Prosecco and craft beer available till late, no queues for anything, tons of entertainment and good music (bouncy castles, lawn games, tarot readings, gladiators, live bands, multiple djs). Actually felt like bang for buck compared to other overpriced com balls with not even half the food and entertainment options

oxlove to the INCREDIBLE Green Templeton Ball Committee, particularly food/drink rep and entz who quite literally commandeered the djs and silent disco booth to queue absolute bops all night long. One of my best nights in Oxford, and an elegant, entertaining, and well-run balls of the year!

I’m now hearing that the Linacre/Thao debacle isn’t simply a name change, but the closing of Linacre and transfer of assets to a completely new college. Donors can now effectively overwrite history at Oxford.
Hot take: renaming Linacre is a small price to pay for increasing their endowment eightfold

The renaming of Linacre to Thao is just evidence that the University care more about their financial endowment than the livelihoods of students of colour. For YEARS students have been demanding Oxford rename institutions, and the counterargument is always the same: 'we cannot hide the history of these places'. Renaming colleges/scholarships/libraries based on modern financial donations entirely undermines this idea and puts a price on the well-being of students. 'We cannot hide the history of these places without financially profiting from that action'. What makes Linacre different from Rhodes and Codrington? Are POC livelihoods at Oxford University worth less than £155 million? This action continues to confirm that the answer is yes.

I feel divided on Linacre's renaming (alum memories of the original name versus actual tangible resources), but I do think there's lots of potential in 'Thao'. It's a Vietnamese surname; the Sino-Viet character for Thao 草 means grass ("grass college") (if we go one step further, 草 means lol/lmao in Japanese slang - "lol college"); with 草 comes a new symbol/logo for the college; it's coincidentally a Thai honorific ("lord/lady"); an aboriginal group in Taiwan; sounds like the Greek letter Tau (physics, maths, etc); and sounds a little like Taoist Tao ("the way"). So many possibilities and new directions! From Taoist Tao and Greek Tau especially there's so much symbolism and wordplay that can be had... way more than the name of some 15th century dude.
